want to share it with the wider side of the world because i may want to get some help from somebody you know like nick
was talking about you know he was maintaining documentation i may want to have some documentation i want a specialty skill set that is sitting out
in the community that can help me build that particular part of it and that's the whole aspect of community around it
there are hundreds and thousands of those projects sitting on github and several other open source repositories
the second kind of open source project is enterprise driven so think about netflix oss or firecracker is one we
contributed last year now these are serving enterprise needs
once they serve their enterprise needs they continue to serve the enterprise needs but then the enterprise thing is
valuable to contribute these projects out in the open source because there is a gap that is identified and then others
can potentially look at that project and leverage it and then start contributing again going back to the basic
fundamentals be able to use it be able to modify it be able to redistribute it
those basic fundamental tenets then there are projects like kafka which were probably started at an enterprise

was started at google but then contributed to cncf for example and see how the projects have really grown
because it really provides a vendor-neutral third party where the projects are growing up and then there's
a fourth kind of project that we have seen which are again extremely successful where lots and lots of
companies have built businesses around open source projects so pick a project there is a company that is sitting on
top of it that is providing support around it that is building commercial plug-ins on top of it and um we were
listening to our presentation yesterday there are 40 plus companies that have 100 million dollar plus revenue on open

our customers love open source i'd say open source you know when i started an open source
and i had to convince enterprises to use open source and was really hard to just get them to you know take open

what is best for our customers as part of that we also try to make sure that it's not just around the code

on the work we've done and in most cases the software actually gets better and that's what i love about
open source is you've got lots of eyeballs and open source you know really helps code quality and security

much like there are so many different events foundations a lot of different stakeholders in this ecosystem uh why is

open source innovation innovation is super critical because i you know i kind of think of open source as a supply

and organizations can drive on top of that you know if we go back to php in kind of the early days um you know
php itself was not just a language right it was all the extensions on top of php where you could interact with xml or

that really enabled us to be successful and so you know when we think about
open source and open source communities there's a there's lots of communities but then also there's the aggregate

stack and we'll talk a bit more about elasticsearch later on where you know
the elasticsearch project right was able to deliver you know really really awesome software right both by

folks to kind of start companies or star projects and not have to kind of invent
all the plumbing themselves but really focus on the innovation on top and the

healthy we've kind of talked about the edges of that a little bit but you mentioned a room that it's

the community um how do we think about healthy open source communities at aws yeah i think
it's very important to think about that of course the code but first part to realize is open source
definitely means source open but that's just one part of it you know the source is sitting on a github repository that
doesn't make it a healthy open source project what makes it is you know how actively you are working on the project
you know how much is the difference between you know your internal product versus that external product it's
perfectly fine to build your proprietary plugins keep them inside but how clear
are the licenses from the end user perspective when the end user is looking at the project you know is it clear to
them that they are contributing to the open source side of the world or to the commercial side of the world that needs
to be very clear you want to make sure that a healthy project the way you look at the health of a project is how many
commits are happening how many commits are happening by you know is it a vendor-driven project or are multiple
you know vendors are actually collaborating on the project you know are the technical discussions
happening in the open you know are the prs are the issues being sent in the open and are they being discussed in the
open or are there are some hallway discussions happening that are not being done transparently out in the public so
i remember from the early sundays one of the things we have to be very very conscious about and remember this is 15
years ago we have to be very conscious about it that if there is a hallway conversation happening then we have to
make sure that we send an explicit email to the members list because the members are not in the hallway so creating that
transparency is fundamentally important to keep that healthy community
yeah so transparency openness uh the ability for others to contribute and be part of the community making it not

is very important actually because code is just one part of it but if you look at a project like kubernetes which

close and nearer to my heart i was part of the original jdk team back at sun
so recently uh oracle uh well there is a standard life process of any jdk release
it goes end of life but then recently oracle changed the licensing as well and how often they're gonna release a jdk
and how much is going to be the overlap between different jdk releases so we realize that we cannot rely upon a
binary distribution of jdk so open jdk is where all the reference
implementation of java is being built it's a completely open source project very nicely done by oracle primarily run
by oracle but then a lot of other vendors are collaborating as well over there so we started building from source
and amazon is a huge java shop and as part of that we said okay we're going to build from source and that's the version
that we're going to start using so internally we call it coretto and then when oracle changed this licensing and the release model we
realized you know what this is not just an aws need our customers are coming to us and as andy talked about we are
customer obsessed 90 to 95 percent of our roadmap is driven by customers and
we realize it's a customer need as well then we started producing an external binary as well so last year at devoxx it
was fun experience james gosling flying from here to devoxx and getting up on the
stage in front of he's the father of java talking about hey you know what we got amazon coretto so what is amazon
current amazon corrado is a downstream distribution of open jdk now
there are a lot of other distributions of open jdk as well but this is a downstream distribution it gives you no
cost long term support so there are two primary versions of opengdk that are
running around right now there is open jdk8 and opengdk11 and so for corresponding to both of those we have
coretta eight and coretta 11. and we are offering no cost long term support to
our customers at least until 2023 or june 2023 for coredo eight and until
august 2024 for corey 11. and one of the core tenets i think which
andy was talking about earlier as well is we there is no intention here to maintain
something internal patches we want to make sure any changes we do to credo are
contributed upstream first because it's very inefficient and expensive for us to
maintain those patches internally so we want to make sure there is a upstream compatibility to open jdk yet provide
that no cost long-term support to our customers right the one thing i would add is you know java came out in 1996 so we're
about you know in the 23rd year of java and so you have you know hundreds of thousands or more enterprise
applications built on java and so when we you know identified that there was going to be a gap for customers right

to the source that we've used to create coretto is pushed back upstream and that's
that's really the differentiating factor between a distribution and a fork right correct because you know if you start
maintaining the changes in there and then there is innovation happening up in the upstream then every time there's a
change happening over there you have to kind of bring it down to the fork so it's very expensive to maintain a fork
in that sense now there could be some reasons for some vendors to maintain a fork but our intent is to have that
upstream compatibility because we believe we any innovation that's happening should happen out in the open source and
you know i also want to add that i don't think it's just because of the you know maintenance piece i think there's another piece which is you know if you

that there's a very clear kind of central place right for that open source to live yeah i think

sure a lot of people have have used it but what are some common use cases or customer stories and
why did we decide to make a distro yeah so elasticsearch is a it's basically called the search engine
but it's much more than that it's basically a search and analytics search engine so you know
when it started out and you know you talk about solar which was kind of a similar project it was really primarily
kind of focused at full text search so you know building things like search on websites and so on and it's got
something called inverted index which is a data structure and you know computer science right that helps you basically
you know take a term take some word right and basically find all the matching documents from that and so that's how people basically kind of
build you know search in a very simplistic manner but what ended up happening was you know lucien became a lot more powerful over
time and actually also added analytics capabilities meaning you can actually you know take a large set of data and do
things like you know some you know certain fields like do aggregation and so on and so forth and
so what elastic search you know ended up becoming is they built on the scene and elasticsearch is basically a
distributed version of lucine so it's this lucine you know full text search with analytics capabilities but it's
distributed and then it was a lot of innovation that went on top of that to create you know apis that were made it
very easy to kind of query that distributed system and visualization that went on top of it
so users could actually very easily find the needle in the haystack and do reporting and so on
and so the the technology is actually i kind of think about it as a swiss army knife you can it can do a lot of different things
i would say the number one use case today um for the technology is
log analytics now you know what is a log a log is a it's basically a data
that applications basically log to some kind of file so it could be at the application level infrastructure level
or it could be iot devices where um you know it may maybe if a user comes to a
website and clicks on a button we kind of log that so we can kind of look at it later on so you get all these logs and
and then what elasticsearch does is it basically takes those logs and indexes them which means it creates
it it inserts that into these data structures that are then easily searchable and easily easy to aggregate
so log analytics at scale is probably the number one use case um which is application infrastructure level a lot
of click stream analytics so for example you know website analytics how many people kind of clicked on this button
versus that button we'll stream into elasticsearch and we'll know how to process that and give you aggregated views
and then we still see quite a lot of what i call that traditional full text search which is implementing search for

is why our customers asked us to build a managed version of it so what what what customer needs

we kind of saw this need right to have a distribution for elasticsearch it's kind of like coretto

learned over the years is that it's really hard to find bottlenecks in elasticsearch elasticsearch is a very
complex system and the tools that come out of the box with elasticsearch they're just reporting on elasticsearch aren't
sufficient to actually be able to identify what's going on so we built in-house this product called
performance analyzer which allows you to query across the operating system and elasticsearch and it runs outside of the
jvm so you can it has its own endpoint so that i can query not only you know what my
jvm pressure is but what my jvm pressure is by workload or what the cpu pressure
is by shard and so or how the network is inter interacting with elasticsearch yes so i
can actually find those bottlenecks so very powerful runtime level analytics of you know what's going on under the hood
to be able to figure that out and optimize those systems yes across the the entire stack not just the application okay and so
